title: Emotional & Physical Connection
description: Explore how emotional closeness and physical intimacy connect for you.

questions.text: For me, emotional connection and physical intimacy are...
choices: Deeply linked—I need one for the other
Related but can exist separately
Physical helps me feel emotionally close
Emotional closeness makes physical better

therapeutic.rationale: The emotional-physical link varies by person. Deeply-linked types can't separate them; separators compartmentalize; physical-first types connect through body; emotional-first types need safety first. Misunderstanding this causes major conflict.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The emotional-first partner may feel used if physical comes before emotional; the physical-first partner may feel rejected waiting for emotional connection. Neither is wrong—understand each other's pathway.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared connection style means you'll naturally sync up. You understand each other's pathway to intimacy.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do emotional and physical connection relate for you? Which comes first, or do they happen together?

questions.text: I feel most emotionally connected to my partner when...
choices: We have deep, meaningful conversations
We share physical closeness and touch
We spend quality time together doing things
They show they really understand me

therapeutic.rationale: Connection pathways reveal love languages. Conversation-connectors bond through words; physical-connectors bond through touch; activity-connectors bond through shared experience; understanding-seekers bond through being known. Partners often differ.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different pathways may mean missing each other's bids for connection. The talker may not realize their partner is connecting through touch; the activity-lover may not realize their partner needs more words.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared connection pathway makes bonding natural. You instinctively give what your partner needs.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When do you feel most connected to your partner? What's happening in those moments?

questions.text: When we're not physically intimate for a while, I tend to...
choices: Feel disconnected and miss the closeness
Not notice much if we're emotionally close
Feel concerned about the relationship
Understand—life gets busy sometimes

therapeutic.rationale: Reactions to intimacy gaps reveal needs and meanings. Disconnection-feelers need physical to feel close; emotion-focusers prioritize other connection; concern-feelers read it as trouble; understanders are flexible. Partners often react differently.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The disconnection-feeler may feel rejected during dry spells; the understander may not realize their partner is struggling. Check in during busy times.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared reactions mean you'll experience intimacy gaps similarly. This alignment helps during stressful seasons.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel when physical intimacy decreases? What meaning do you make of it?

questions.text: After being physically intimate, I usually want to...
choices: Stay close, cuddle, and connect
Have some quiet time together
Talk and share what's on my mind
Go about normal activities feeling good

therapeutic.rationale: Post-intimacy needs reveal how you process connection. Cuddlers extend closeness; quiet-timers process internally; talkers deepen through words; activity-resumers feel complete. Mismatched needs can hurt feelings.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The cuddler may feel abandoned if their partner gets up; the activity-resumer may feel smothered by extended closeness. Share your needs without judgment.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched post-intimacy needs create seamless transitions. You naturally want the same thing after.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you need after being physically intimate? What makes you feel most cared for?

questions.text: The balance between emotional and physical intimacy I want is...
choices: Heavy on emotional, physical flows from there
Heavy on physical, it creates emotional closeness
Equal emphasis on both
Flexible depending on the season of life

therapeutic.rationale: Desired intimacy balance reveals priorities. Emotional-heavy types need feelings first; physical-heavy types connect through body; equal-balancers want both; flexible types adapt. Articulating your ideal helps your partner understand.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different balance preferences need negotiation. The emotional-heavy partner may feel the physical-heavy partner is shallow; the physical-heavy partner may feel the emotional-heavy partner is withholding.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared balance preference aligns your intimacy expectations. You're naturally aiming for the same relationship.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What balance of emotional and physical intimacy feels ideal to you? What does that look like day-to-day?
